concern.cve-metadata: CVE-2022-43552||scap_title=Use after free Vulnerability in curl||desc=A use after free vulnerability exists in curl <7.87.0. Curl can be asked to *tunnel* virtually all protocols it supports through an HTTP proxy. HTTP proxies can (and often do) deny such tunnel operations. When getting denied to tunnel the specific protocols SMB or TELNET, curl would use a heap-allocated struct after it had been freed, in its transfer shutdown code path.||ext_ref=20230327 APPLE-SA-2023-03-27-3 macOS Ventura 13.3 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Mar/17,https://hackerone.com/reports/1764858 MISC https://hackerone.com/reports/1764858,https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20230214-0002/ CONFIRM https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20230214-0002/,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213670 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213670||publisheddate=2023-02-09||modifieddate=2023-03-28||score=5.9||cvss3_exploit_score=2.2||cvss3_impact_score=3.6||cvss3_attack_vector=NETWORK||cvss3_attack_complexity=HIGH||cvss3_privileges_required=NONE||cvss3_user_interaction=NONE||cvss3_scope=UNCHANGED||cvss3_confidentiality=NONE||cvss3_integrity=NONE||cvss3_availability=HIGH||||tags=null

concern.cve-metadata: CVE-2022-43551||scap_title=UTF-8 U+3002 (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) Vulnerability in curl HSTS check||desc=A vulnerability exists in curl <7.87.0 HSTS check that could be bypassed to trick it to keep using HTTP. Using its HSTS support, curl can be instructed to use HTTPS instead of using an insecure clear-text HTTP step even when HTTP is provided in the URL. However, the HSTS mechanism could be bypassed if the host name in the given URL first uses IDN characters that get replaced to ASCII counterparts as part of the IDN conversion. Like using the character UTF-8 U+3002 (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) instead of the common ASCII full stop (U+002E) `.`. Then in a subsequent request, it does not detect the HSTS state and makes a clear text transfer. Because it would store the info IDN encoded but look for it IDN decoded.||ext_ref=https://hackerone.com/reports/1755083 MISC https://hackerone.com/reports/1755083,https://lists.fedoraproject.org/archives/list/package-announce%40lists.fedoraproject.org/message/TVWZW5CNSJ7UYAF2BGSYAWAEXDJYUBHA/ MISC https://lists.fedoraproject.org/archives/list/package-announce%40lists.fedoraproject.org/message/TVWZW5CNSJ7UYAF2BGSYAWAEXDJYUBHA/,https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20230427-0007/ MISC https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20230427-0007/||publisheddate=2022-12-23||modifieddate=2023-04-27||score=7.5||cvss3_exploit_score=3.9||cvss3_impact_score=3.6||cvss3_attack_vector=NETWORK||cvss3_attack_complexity=LOW||cvss3_privileges_required=NONE||cvss3_user_interaction=NONE||cvss3_scope=UNCHANGED||cvss3_confidentiality=HIGH||cvss3_integrity=NONE||cvss3_availability=NONE||||tags=null
concern.desc: UTF-8 U+3002 (IDEOGRAPHIC FULL STOP) Vulnerability in curl HSTS check

concern.cve-metadata: CVE-2023-28319||scap_title=Use After Free Vulnerability in curl for SSH Server's Public Key Verification||desc=A use after free vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 in the way libcurl offers a feature to verify an SSH server's public key using a SHA 256 hash. When this check fails, libcurl would free the memory for the fingerprint before it returns an error message containing the (now freed) hash. This flaw risks inserting sensitive heap-based data into the error message that might be shown to users or otherwise get leaked and revealed.||ext_ref=20230725 APPLE-SA-2023-07-24-4 macOS Ventura 13.5 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Jul/47,20230725 APPLE-SA-2023-07-24-5 macOS Monterey 12.6.8 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Jul/48,20230725 APPLE-SA-2023-07-24-6 macOS Big Sur 11.7.9 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Jul/52,https://hackerone.com/reports/1913733 MISC https://hackerone.com/reports/1913733,https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20230609-0009/ CONFIRM https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20230609-0009/,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213843 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213843,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213844 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213844,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213845 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213845||publisheddate=2023-05-26||modifieddate=2023-08-02||score=7.5||cvss3_exploit_score=3.9||cvss3_impact_score=3.6||cvss3_attack_vector=NETWORK||cvss3_attack_complexity=LOW||cvss3_privileges_required=NONE||cvss3_user_interaction=NONE||cvss3_scope=UNCHANGED||cvss3_confidentiality=HIGH||cvss3_integrity=NONE||cvss3_availability=NONE||||tags=null

concern.cve-metadata: CVE-2023-28320||scap_title=Denial of Service Vulnerability in curl DNS Resolver||desc=A denial of service vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 in the way libcurl provides several different backends for resolving host names, selected at build time. If it is built to use the synchronous resolver, it allows name resolves to time-out slow operations using `alarm()` and `siglongjmp()`. When doing this, libcurl used a global buffer that was not mutex protected and a multi-threaded application might therefore crash or otherwise misbehave.||ext_ref=20230725 APPLE-SA-2023-07-24-4 macOS Ventura 13.5 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Jul/47,20230725 APPLE-SA-2023-07-24-5 macOS Monterey 12.6.8 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Jul/48,20230725 APPLE-SA-2023-07-24-6 macOS Big Sur 11.7.9 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Jul/52,https://hackerone.com/reports/1929597 MISC https://hackerone.com/reports/1929597,https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20230609-0009/ CONFIRM https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20230609-0009/,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213843 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213843,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213844 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213844,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213845 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213845||publisheddate=2023-05-26||modifieddate=2023-08-02||score=5.9||cvss3_exploit_score=2.2||cvss3_impact_score=3.6||cvss3_attack_vector=NETWORK||cvss3_attack_complexity=HIGH||cvss3_privileges_required=NONE||cvss3_user_interaction=NONE||cvss3_scope=UNCHANGED||cvss3_confidentiality=NONE||cvss3_integrity=NONE||cvss3_availability=HIGH||||tags=null
concern.desc: Denial of Service Vulnerability in curl DNS Resolver

concern.cve-metadata: CVE-2023-28321||scap_title=Improper Certificate Validation Vulnerability in curl accepting wildcard patterns||desc=An improper certificate validation vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 in the way it supports matching of wildcard patterns when listed as "Subject Alternative Name" in TLS server certificates. curl can be built to use its own name matching function for TLS rather than one provided by a TLS library. This private wildcard matching function would match IDN (International Domain Name) hosts incorrectly and could as a result accept patterns that otherwise should mismatch. IDN hostnames are converted to puny code before used for certificate checks. Puny coded names always start with `xn--` and should not be allowed to pattern match, but the wildcard check in curl could still check for `x*`, which would match even though the IDN name most likely contained nothing even resembling an `x`.||ext_ref=20230725 APPLE-SA-2023-07-24-4 macOS Ventura 13.5 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Jul/47,20230725 APPLE-SA-2023-07-24-5 macOS Monterey 12.6.8 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Jul/48,20230725 APPLE-SA-2023-07-24-6 macOS Big Sur 11.7.9 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Jul/52,FEDORA-2023-37eac50e9b FEDORA https://lists.fedoraproject.org/archives/list/package-announce@lists.fedoraproject.org/message/F4I75RDGX5ULSSCBE5BF3P5I5SFO7ULQ/,FEDORA-2023-8ed627bb04 FEDORA https://lists.fedoraproject.org/archives/list/package-announce@lists.fedoraproject.org/message/Z2LIWHWKOVH24COGGBCVOWDXXIUPKOMK/,https://hackerone.com/reports/1950627 MISC https://hackerone.com/reports/1950627,https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20230609-0009/ CONFIRM https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20230609-0009/,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213843 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213843,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213844 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213844,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213845 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213845||publisheddate=2023-05-26||modifieddate=2023-08-02||score=5.9||cvss3_exploit_score=2.2||cvss3_impact_score=3.6||cvss3_attack_vector=NETWORK||cvss3_attack_complexity=HIGH||cvss3_privileges_required=NONE||cvss3_user_interaction=NONE||cvss3_scope=UNCHANGED||cvss3_confidentiality=NONE||cvss3_integrity=HIGH||cvss3_availability=NONE||||tags=null
concern.desc: Improper Certificate Validation Vulnerability in curl accepting wildcard patterns

concern.cve-metadata: CVE-2023-28322||scap_title=Information Disclosure Vulnerability in curl when doing HTTP(S) transfers||desc=An information disclosure vulnerability exists in curl <v8.1.0 when doing HTTP(S) transfers, libcurl might erroneously use the read callback (`CURLOPT_READFUNCTION`) to ask for data to send, even when the `CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` option has been set, if the same handle previously wasused to issue a `PUT` request which used that callback. This flaw may surprise the application and cause it to misbehave and either send off the wrong data or use memory after free or similar in the second transfer. The problem exists in the logic for a reused handle when it is (expected to be) changed from a PUT to a POST.||ext_ref=20230725 APPLE-SA-2023-07-24-4 macOS Ventura 13.5 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Jul/47,20230725 APPLE-SA-2023-07-24-5 macOS Monterey 12.6.8 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Jul/48,20230725 APPLE-SA-2023-07-24-6 macOS Big Sur 11.7.9 FULLDISC http://seclists.org/fulldisclosure/2023/Jul/52,FEDORA-2023-37eac50e9b FEDORA https://lists.fedoraproject.org/archives/list/package-announce@lists.fedoraproject.org/message/F4I75RDGX5ULSSCBE5BF3P5I5SFO7ULQ/,FEDORA-2023-8ed627bb04 FEDORA https://lists.fedoraproject.org/archives/list/package-announce@lists.fedoraproject.org/message/Z2LIWHWKOVH24COGGBCVOWDXXIUPKOMK/,https://hackerone.com/reports/1954658 MISC https://hackerone.com/reports/1954658,https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20230609-0009/ CONFIRM https://security.netapp.com/advisory/ntap-20230609-0009/,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213843 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213843,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213844 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213844,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213845 CONFIRM https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213845||publisheddate=2023-05-26||modifieddate=2023-08-02||score=3.7||cvss3_exploit_score=2.2||cvss3_impact_score=1.4||cvss3_attack_vector=NETWORK||cvss3_attack_complexity=HIGH||cvss3_privileges_required=NONE||cvss3_user_interaction=NONE||cvss3_scope=UNCHANGED||cvss3_confidentiality=LOW||cvss3_integrity=NONE||cvss3_availability=NONE||||tags=null

concern.cve-metadata:
CVE-2023-34241||scap_title=Use-after-Free Vulnerability in OpenPrinting CUPS||desc=OpenPrinting CUPS is a standards-based, open source printing system for Linux and other Unix-like operating systems. Starting in version 2.0.0 and prior to version 2.4.6, CUPS logs data of free memory to the logging service AFTER the connection has been closed, when it should have logged the data right before. This is a use-after-free bug that impacts the entire cupsd process.

The exact cause of this issue is the function `httpClose(con->http)` being called in `scheduler/client.c`. The problem is that httpClose always, provided its argument is not null, frees the pointer at the end of the call, only for cupsdLogClient to pass the pointer to httpGetHostname. This issue happens in function `cupsdAcceptClient` if LogLevel is warn or higher and in two scenarios: there is a double-lookup for the IP Address (HostNameLookups Double is set in `cupsd.conf`) which fails to resolve, or if CUPS is compiled with TCP wrappers and the connection is refused by rules from `/etc/hosts.allow` and `/etc/hosts.deny`.

Version 2.4.6 has a patch for this issue.||ext_ref=http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2023/06/23/10 MISC http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2023/06/23/10,http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2023/06/26/1 MISC http://www.openwall.com/lists/oss-security/2023/06/26/1,https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups/commit/9809947a959e18409dcf562a3466ef246cb90cb2 MISC https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups/commit/9809947a959e18409dcf562a3466ef246cb90cb2,https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups/releases/tag/v2.4.6 MISC https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups/releases/tag/v2.4.6,https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups/security/advisories/GHSA-qjgh-5hcq-5f25 MISC https://github.com/OpenPrinting/cups/security/advisories/GHSA-qjgh-5hcq-5f25,https://lists.debian.org/debian-lts-announce/2023/06/msg00038.html MISC https://lists.debian.org/debian-lts-announce/2023/06/msg00038.html,https://lists.fedoraproject.org/archives/list/package-announce@lists.fedoraproject.org/message/7I7DWGYGEMBNLZF5UQBMF3SONR37YUBN/ MISC https://lists.fedoraproject.org/archives/list/package-announce@lists.fedoraproject.org/message/7I7DWGYGEMBNLZF5UQBMF3SONR37YUBN/,https://lists.fedoraproject.org/archives/list/package-announce@lists.fedoraproject.org/message/TBIYKDS3UG3W4Z7YOHTR2AWFNBRYPNYY/ MISC https://lists.fedoraproject.org/archives/list/package-announce@lists.fedoraproject.org/message/TBIYKDS3UG3W4Z7YOHTR2AWFNBRYPNYY/,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213843 MISC https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213843,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213844 MISC https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213844,https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213845 MISC https://support.apple.com/kb/HT213845||publisheddate=2023-06-22||modifieddate=2023-07-28||score=7.1||cvss3_exploit_score=1.8||cvss3_impact_score=5.2||cvss3_attack_vector=LOCAL||cvss3_attack_complexity=LOW||cvss3_privileges_required=LOW||cvss3_user_interaction=NONE||cvss3_scope=UNCHANGED||cvss3_confidentiality=HIGH||cvss3_integrity=NONE||cvss3_availability=HIGH||||tags=null

concern.cce-metadata:
CCE-50043-9||scap_title=Enable macOS update installs||platform=cpe:/o:apple:mac_os_13||desc=This setting allows macOS updates to be installed automatically once they are available from Apple. Because patches need to be applied as soon as possible, allowing for automatic updates ensures that the user's device is updated in a timely manner rather than be left vulnerable to additional security risks.
Fix:

concern.desc: Set the Global UMASK Setting for system processes
concern.cce-metadata:
CCE-50046-2||scap_title=Set the Global Umask Setting for System Process||platform=cpe:/o:apple:mac_os_13||desc=The default global umask setting must be set to '027' for user applications. The setting '027' ensures that user created files and directories will be readable, but not writable, by users that share the same group id. Users with a different group id will not be able to read or write those files. This mitigates the risk that unauthorized users might be able to read and write files saved to the system by user applications.

Fix:
To set the umask setting for user applications, run the following command:
       sudo launchctl config system umask 027||parameter=<parameters>
<parameter>[027/022/002]</parameter>
</parameters>||technical_mechanism=<technical_mechanisms>
<technical_mechanism>To set the umask setting for user applications, run the following command:
       sudo launchctl config user umask 027</technical_mechanism>
</technical_mechanisms>||ref=<references>
<reference resource_id="SCAP Repo OVAL Definition">oval:org.secpod.oval:def:85867</reference>

concern.desc: Application Firewall should be enabled or disabled as appropriate
concern.cce-metadata:
CCE-50070-2||scap_title=Enable Application Firewall||platform=cpe:/o:apple:mac_os_13||desc=The Application Firewall is the built in firewall that comes with Mac OS X and must be enabled. Firewalls protect computers from network attacks by blocking or limiting access to open network ports. Application firewalls limit which applications are allowed to communicate over the network.

Fix:
To enable the firewall run the following command:

sudo /usr/libexec/ApplicationFirewall/socketfilterfw --setglobalstate on||parameter=<parameters>
<parameter>[yes/no]</parameter>
</parameters>||technical_mechanism=<technical_mechanisms>

concern.desc: Numeric Character in Passwords
concern.cce-metadata:
CCE-50073-6||scap_title=Numeric Character in Passwords||platform=cpe:/o:apple:mac_os_13||desc=Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

Password complexity is one factor of several that determine how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

Fix:
To set the password policy, run the following command:

sudo pwpolicy setglobalpolicy 'requiresNumeric=1'||parameter=<parameters>
<parameter>[enable/disable]</parameter>
</parameters>||technical_mechanism=<technical_mechanisms>
<technical_mechanism>To set the password policy, run the following command:

sudo pwpolicy setglobalpolicy 'requiresNumeric=1'</technical_mechanism>
</technical_mechanisms>||ref=<references>
<reference resource_id="SCAP Repo OVAL Definition">oval:org.secpod.oval:def:85894</reference>
</references>||ccss_score=8.1||attack_vector=NETWORK||attack_complexity=HIGH||privileges_required=HIGH||user_interaction=NONE||scope=UNCHANGED||confidentiality_impact=HIGH||integrity_impact=HIGH||availability_impact=HIGH||exploit_subscore=2.2||impact_subscore=5.9||ccss_vector=(AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H)||ccss_severity=HIGH||||tags=null

concern.desc: Maximum password lifetime restriction
concern.cce-metadata:
CCE-50075-1||scap_title=Maximum password lifetime restriction||platform=cpe:/o:apple:mac_os_13||desc=Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically.

One method of minimizing this risk is to use complex passwords and periodically change them. If the operating system does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that the operating system passwords could be compromised.

Fix:
To set the password policy, run the following command:

sudo pwpolicy setglobalpolicy 'maxMinutesUntilChangePassword=86400'

Note:
This patch is known to cause issues with root login incases where root account password was never set. If using root account ensure password is set before patching. Incase of issues consider rolling back the patch.||parameter=<parameters>
<parameter>[Seconds]</parameter>
</parameters>||technical_mechanism=<technical_mechanisms>
<technical_mechanism>To set the password policy, run the following command:

sudo pwpolicy setglobalpolicy 'maxMinutesUntilChangePassword=86400'</technical_mechanism>
</technical_mechanisms>||ref=<references>
<reference resource_id="SCAP Repo OVAL Definition">oval:org.secpod.oval:def:85896</reference>
</references>||ccss_score=8.1||attack_vector=NETWORK||attack_complexity=HIGH||privileges_required=NONE||user_interaction=NONE||scope=UNCHANGED||confidentiality_impact=HIGH||integrity_impact=HIGH||availability_impact=HIGH||exploit_subscore=2.2||impact_subscore=5.9||ccss_vector=(AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H)||ccss_severity=HIGH||||tags=null

concern.desc: Disable the guest account
concern.cce-metadata: CCE-50057-9||scap_title=Disable guest account login||platform=cpe:/o:apple:mac_os_13||desc=The Guest account, a special managed account, is considered a security vulnerability in most situations because it has no password associated with it. Once an attacker has gained guest-level access, the attacker can try to elevate privileges to further exploit a system. We recommend that the Guest account be disabled on all macOS systems unless there is a clearly demonstrated need to use a Guest account. The Guest account is not allowed to log in to a computer by default. However, guest users can access shared folders remotely by default. This setting is called "Allow guest users to connect to shared folders" and should be disabled. Both of these settings are available under System Preferences / Users and Groups / Guest Userand are disabled by default. Note that when a guest logs out of a macOS system, the guest's environment is destroyed and reinitialized. Fix: defaults write /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow GuestEnabled -bool FALSE||parameter= [Hide/Display] ||technical_mechanism= defaults write /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow GuestEnabled -bool FALSE ||ref= resource_id=SCAP Repo OVAL Definition oval:org.secpod.oval:def:85878 ||ccss_score=7.3||attack_vector=NETWORK||attack_complexity=LOW||privileges_required=NONE||user_interaction=NONE||scope=UNCHANGED||confidentiality_impact=LOW||integrity_impact=LOW||availability_impact=LOW||exploit_subscore=3.9||impact_subscore=3.4||ccss_vector=(AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:L)||ccss_severity=HIGH||||tags=null

concern.desc: Gatekeeper should be enabled or disabled as appropriate
concern.cce-metadata: CCE-50065-2||scap_title=Enable Gatekeeper||platform=cpe:/o:apple:mac_os_13||desc=Gatekeeper settings must be configured correctly to only allow the system to run applications downloaded from the Mac App Store. Administator users will still have the option to override these settings on a per app basis. Gatekeeper is a security feature that ensures that applications must be digitally signed by an Apple issued certificate in order to run. Digital signatures allow Mac OS X to verify that the application has not been modified by a malicious third party. Fix: This setting is enforced using a configuration profile.||parameter= [yes/no] ||technical_mechanism= This setting is enforced using a configuration profile. ||ref= resource_id=SCAP Repo OVAL Definition oval:org.secpod.oval:def:85886 ||ccss_score=8.4||attack_vector=LOCAL||attack_complexity=LOW||privileges_required=NONE||user_interaction=NONE||scope=UNCHANGED||confidentiality_impact=HIGH||integrity_impact=HIGH||availability_impact=HIGH||exploit_subscore=2.5||impact_subscore=5.9||ccss_vector=(AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H)||ccss_severity=HIGH||||tags=null

concern.desc: Password hints on lock screen
concern.cce-metadata: CCE-50085-0||scap_title=Password hints on lock screen||platform=cpe:/o:apple:mac_os_13||desc=By default, Mac OS X obligingly displays the password hint for an account after three unsuccessful attempts at entering a password. Where security is an issue, this is like serving a hacker a piece of apple pie. Therefore, head to System Preferences, display the Accounts settings, click the Login Options button, and make sure that the Show Password Hints check box is empty. Fix: defaults write /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow RetriesUntilHint -int X||parameter= [no/yes] ||technical_mechanism= defaults write /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow RetriesUntilHint -int X ||ref= resource_id=SCAP Repo OVAL Definition oval:org.secpod.oval:def:85905 ||ccss_score=6.8||attack_vector=PHYSICAL||attack_complexity=LOW||privileges_required=NONE||user_interaction=NONE||scope=UNCHANGED||confidentiality_impact=HIGH||integrity_impact=HIGH||availability_impact=HIGH||exploit_subscore=0.9||impact_subscore=5.9||ccss_vector=(AV:P/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H)||ccss_severity=MEDIUM||||tags=null

concern.desc: Prevent Users from Logging in as Root Directly
concern.cce-metadata: CCE-50097-5||scap_title=Prevent Users from Logging in as Root Directly||platform=cpe:/o:apple:mac_os_13||desc=Administrator users must never log in directly as root. To assure individual accountability and prevent unauthorized access, logging in as root over a remote connection must be disabled. Administrators should only run commands as root after first authenticating with their individual user names and passwords. Fix: In order to make sure that PermitRootLogin is disabled by sshd, run the following command: sudo sed -i.bak 's/^[#]*PermitRootLogin.*/PermitRootLogin no/' /etc/sshd_config||parameter= [no/yes] ||technical_mechanism= In order to make sure that PermitRootLogin is disabled by sshd, run the following command: sudo sed -i.bak 's/^[\#]*PermitRootLogin.*/PermitRootLogin no/' /etc/sshd_config ||ref= resource_id=SCAP Repo OVAL Definition oval:org.secpod.oval:def:85916 ||ccss_score=7.2||attack_vector=NETWORK||attack_complexity=LOW||privileges_required=HIGH||user_interaction=NONE||scope=UNCHANGED||confidentiality_impact=HIGH||integrity_impact=HIGH||availability_impact=HIGH||exploit_subscore=1.2||impact_subscore=5.9||ccss_vector=(AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H)||ccss_severity=HIGH||||tags=null

concern.desc: Automatic Logons should be enabled or disabled as appropriate
concern.cce-metadata: CCE-50104-9||scap_title=Disable Automatic Logons||platform=cpe:/o:apple:mac_os_13||desc=When automatic logins are enabled, the default user account is automatically logged in at boot time without prompting the user for a password. Even if the screen is later locked, a malicious user would be able to reboot the computer in order to log in. Disabling automatic logins mitigates this risk.
